G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody judgment when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred since entry of the prior order, and a modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody judgment when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred since entry of the prior order, and a modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter under G.L. c. 215, § 6, and venue properly lies in the **Bristol County Probate and Family Court**, as both parties and the minor child reside in Bristol County.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: A “material and substantial change in circumstances” justifying modification exists when conditions that formed the basis of the original judgment have altered such that enforcement of the prior order would no longer serve the child’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion is not a modification case and does not discuss what constitutes a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ for modifying an existing custody or support order. Instead it sets out the ‘real advantage’ best‑interests test for initial removal and custody determinations under G.L. c. 208, § 30. Because it neither articulates nor applies a material‑change standard for modification, it does not support the claimed proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: A “material and substantial change in circumstances” justifying modification exists when conditions that formed the basis of the original judgment have altered such that enforcement of the prior order would no longer serve the child’s welfare.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly applies the statutory standard that a modification of custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28 requires a "material and substantial change in circumstances" and ties that requirement to whether a transfer of custody would be conducive to the child’s welfare. The court explains that a prior custody judgment is presumed correct and that only changes of sufficient magnitude, since the prior order, that affect the child’s welfare can justify modification. This aligns with the proposition that modification is warranted when the underlying conditions have altered such that enforcing the prior order no longer serves the child’s welfare.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the best interests of the child remain the paramount consideration in modification proceedings.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case is a first-instance custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not a modification proceeding under § 20 or analogous modification standards. While the opinion repeatedly affirms that the best interests of the child are the governing and paramount consideration in custody matters generally, it explicitly declines to apply the modification standard and does not address what standard governs modification proceedings. Thus it does not provide authority for the proposition about Massachusetts law in modification contexts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (custody award is subject to revision ‘as the best interests of the child may demand’).”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the best interests of the child remain the paramount consideration in modification proceedings.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion applies and discusses the best-interests-of-the-child standard in an initial care and protection/adoption context under G.L. c. 210, § 3, not in a post-judgment modification proceeding. The court does not address modification standards or state that best interests remain the paramount consideration in modification proceedings; it simply reiterates that best interests control in choosing between competing adoption plans once parental unfitness is found. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modification proceedings.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that the best interests of the child remain the paramount consideration in modification proceedings.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The case is an alimony modification case and does not concern custody or visitation. The court’s discussion of modification focuses entirely on G.L. c. 208 §§ 34 and 37, need, and ability to pay; there is no mention of children’s best interests as a standard for modification. Thus, it does not establish or affirm that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in modification proceedings under Massachusetts law.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.” Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation. In considering Rudolph’s appeal from the modification judgment, we recognize that a judge enjoys considerable discretion in fashioning an appropriate modification judgment…

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Substantial, unexcused school absences and educational decline constitute a significant change affecting the child’s welfare under Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a relocation / removal case focused on best interests analysis where parents share joint physical custody. The opinion does not discuss substantial, unexcused school absences, nor does it address educational decline as a “significant change affecting the child’s welfare” for modification purposes. Its educational discussion compares relative school quality for best-interests in a proposed move, not a material change in circumstances based on absenteeism or decline, so it does not support the proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order denying permission for the mother to remove the children. The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: Rolde concerns initial divorce, property division, and custody/visitation between two parents. The opinion does not discuss substantial or unexcused school absences, academic decline, or educational performance as a basis for modifying custody or as a change in circumstances affecting the child’s welfare. Its custody analysis is framed entirely in terms of parental conflict, primary caretaker status, and the feasibility of joint custody, so it does not provide authority for the specific educational-change proposition stated.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education, as well as in day-to-day decision making and philosophy of discipline, an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare. That determination has ample support in the record.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Substantial, unexcused school absences and educational decline constitute a significant change affecting the child’s welfare under Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Vaughn does not address modification standards, "material and substantial change in circumstances," or school attendance/educational decline as a change affecting the child’s welfare. Its focus is on initial custody determination and the need for explicit findings on the effects of domestic violence. The only references to schooling indicate that the child was doing well in school, and the court does not treat school performance (good or bad) as a change in circumstances, so the case does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "The judge found that Vaughn 'is doing well at school. His guidance counsellor is hopeful he will continue to shine in school as he did during his last marking period.' ... The judge found that 'The mother acknowledges that [Ross] is most interested in [Vaughn] and is involved in [Vaughn’s] activities. . . . She acknowledges that [Ross] "really cares about [Vaughn]." He is affectionate and concerned about his education.'"

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A parent’s failure to cooperate regarding educational decisions and adherence to the original parenting order further supports modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion never discusses parental cooperation regarding educational decisions or adherence to an original parenting order, nor does it treat such conduct as a basis for modification. Instead, it focuses on the requirement that custody decisions be based on the child’s welfare and rejects using custody as a device to discipline a parent for shortcomings. Thus, it does not support the claimed proposition about failure to cooperate on educational issues justifying modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Such ‘conduct on [his] part cannot be permitted to interfere with the welfare of the child, the paramount and governing consideration.’ … The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’ … ‘Custody is not a prize . . .’”

Cooper v. Cooper, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130.proposition: A parent’s failure to cooperate regarding educational decisions and adherence to the original parenting order further supports modification.
Cooper v. Cooper, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130.support_reasoning: The opinion is about modification of child support and alimony based on the father’s dramatically increased income and lifestyle disparity, plus related attorney’s fees and contempt issues. It does not discuss parental cooperation or non-cooperation regarding educational decision-making, nor failure to adhere to an original parenting (custody/visitation/decision-making) order as a basis for modification. The modification here is grounded in financial changes and needs, not in decision-making or educational disputes, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
Cooper v. Cooper, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 130.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s stated bases for these modifications were (1) changes in the parties’ circumstances, including Philip’s substantially increased income as well as the delay in the sale of the Weston house and the attendant financial burdens that this imposed on Peggy; (2) the needs of the children, determined ‘in the context of their former station in life,’ their father’s higher standard of living, and changes in the children’s emotional and physical health since the divorce; and (3) Philip’s trial stipulations, in which he agreed to be solely responsible for the costs associated with the private school and college educations of the three children….”

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: Where a shared legal custody arrangement becomes “unworkable or detrimental to the child’s welfare,” modification to grant one parent final decision-making authority, or to adjust physical custody, is appropriate.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: This decision is a care and protection / termination-type case between the parents and the Department of Social Services, not a parenting-plan modification case between two parents with shared legal custody. The opinion does not discuss shared or joint legal custody, unworkability of such arrangements, or granting one parent final decision‑making authority; instead it focuses on parental unfitness and the standard of proof for committing children to the Department’s permanent custody. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for modifying a shared legal custody arrangement that has become unworkable or detrimental to the child’s welfare.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: “A decision to remove children permanently from the home of their natural parents must be supported by clear and convincing evidence that the parents are currently unfit to care and provide for their children… The court is permitted to assess prognostic evidence derived from prior patterns of parental neglect or misconduct in determining future fitness and the likelihood of harm to the child.” (396 Mass. at 619-21).

App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The case deals with a custodial parent’s request to remove children from the Commonwealth and the standards for evaluating removal in light of the children’s best interests and the custodial parent’s well‑being. It does not involve shared legal custody, unworkable joint decision‑making, or modification to grant one parent final decision‑making authority or to adjust physical custody due to joint custody breakdown. The opinion focuses on relocation and visitation, not modification of a shared custody arrangement that has become unworkable or detrimental.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice… on the parent having the primary responsibility for the day-to-day care of the children.”
